title: Will ACLED record any civilian fatalities in Angola in October 2017?
preds: None as of Oct. 29, per ACLED.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Dropping to zero simply for passage of time.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Passage of time: No ALCED reports through Oct. 14.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Passage of time: ALCED clean through Oct. 7.

New President—albeit hand-picked by his predecessor—promising change. Things may indeed be different, even if just for a little while, at the outset of a new presidency.
Still, it would take only one civilian death.
Hedging some with my percentage.

There are five cases with fatalities reported so far this year. Suggests that monthly probability should be around 50%, but a third of the month has already passed without incidence. Probability for the remaining 20 days would therefore be around 33%.

Violence gainst civilians still provide opportunity:
Sept 17: Unita supporter shot by police (no death)
Sept 27: 2 Unita supporters dowsed with gasoline but survived the attack.
Maintaining forecast on consideration of the base rate analysis of @cpschneider at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/585442. Thank you, Christian Schneider.

Reading the question more thoroughly, the fine print says that it will only include cases of Violence against civilians or remote violence. Using my same approach as below, but removing sources of riots and battles, my number should be more in the range of 41%.

I used a similar approach to the one I used to calculate the same answer for zimbabwe. I looked at the historical data from angola for the last 5 months and used that to calculate an average number of events per month, as well as the likelihood that those end up in fatalities. Based on the data, no riots resulted in casualties with an average of 6.2 events per month, in cases of violence against civilians, there is a 22% chance that it results in a casualty, with an average of 3.6 events per month, and a 100% likelihood that a battle will result in civilian casualties with .2 per month. Since there was only one battle reported, this data is skewed, so I will use the data from the entirety of africa to get a better statistic which shows that only 66% result in civilian casualties. Also, the fact that 0% of riots resulted in death seemed similarly skewed, as a 0% chance seems impossible. The data from zimbabwe showed a 4.4% chance, as a comparison for scale. Since it appears that riots in angola are safer I will use a number of 1.5 % to still take this into account to some extent. Using these numbers I estimate that there is a 40.9% likelihood of violence against civilians resulting in a casualty, and a 13 % chance that a battle will, and a 9% chance that riots will. Combining these numbers yields a 52% liklihood that violence will result in a casualty in october.
Endemic protests and 1+ fatalities in most months.

Taking months with fatalities relevant to the question as the unit of analysis, the overall rate of occurrence of a relevant events seems to be 35% over the 249 months on record. However, there is almost certainly an overestimation of the base rate, as the rate of occurrence at the beginning of the time series was 83% to 100% over a period of five years. Focusing on the second decade on record (2007-2016), the rate of occurrence is 20% (23 out of 120 months). As there are no apparent seasonal variations except for the third quarter of the year (in the past decade, there were no relevant fatalities in the third quarter in only 3 years as compared to 5 and 7 years in the other three quarters) and the overall rate of occurrence per month is similar in most months except for July, 20% served as a base rate for this estimate. This year, relevant incidents have been recorded in three months, so far. Based on data of the previous decade, this is not an unusual number – there were three years in the past decade with 4 months in which relevant incidents were recorded, in one year this number was three and in six year the number was between 0 and 2. An additional month in which a relevant incident could be recorded is, therefore, not entirely unlikely. With three remaining months this year and all three months having been similarly affected in the past decade (October: 3 out of 10, November: 2 out of 1o, December: 2 out of 10), only a slight adjustment above the base rate seems to be justified.  Some of the relevant incidents recorded this year seemed to have been related to the elections in August according to the ACLED data-set. The new president was sworn in recently without triggering violence so far. Nevertheless, the resignation of the long-time opposition leader and the subsequent need to hold a party congress to elect his successor adds some uncertainties to the situation. Although it is not yet clear when this congress will be held, a further slight adjustment seems reasonable.
very slowly reacting in most of cases

6 total in 2017.  Have seen deaths from remote violence/violence against civilians in 3 of 9 months so far in 2017.  From basic view maybe 33% chance.  But none recorded in October in Angola since 2012, and nothing recorded so far in either August or September, so dropping probability to 15%.
Successful recent transition of power makes political violence less likely. However, other kinds of violence are certainly possible even in a month's timeframe.

This is based on a brief review of historical ACLED data on civilian fatalities in Angola, with no particular qualitative research or context on Angola. I first looked at the likelihood of violence occurring on any given day (~0.8%) and used that to determine the likelihood that there would be at least 1 day in the month of October on which a civilian was killed, which was about 21%. However, this could be slightly skewed upward by months in which there were lots of civilian fatality events. To account for that, I also looked at the likelihood of a civilian fatality in any given month, which was about 17%. I averaged the two to get ~19%. I will probably update further after additional research on the country and as the time frame elapses.
In Angola there is a strong presidential system, that lowered violence, although violence against civilists have risen. After the elections protests are rising, also on economic issues.
5 this year, 3 in July. Going with 5/8.5=
Thank you, @acohen, for your base rate data and analysis. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/573815

Viele Faktoren lassen diese Frage mit Ja beantworten. Zum einen die herruntergesetzte Hemmschwelle oder auch politische Konflikte. Jedoch ist in letzter Zeit eine Entspannung der konfliktauslösenden Faktoren zu erkennen.
Normal distribution built on data over 2017 pegs the odds at 82%.

Deadly events in Angola seem rare but do happen, although at a rate of one or less per month (eyeballing it, didn't feel like do any math). That said, since May nearly all violence has been political and now that the election is over I think the risk of violence drops quite a bit. However, the incident in September was over a confiscated motorcycle so anything can happen.

While Violence against civilians events are relatively frequent, those that include fatalities are not.  Remote violence incidents are rare. In the 60-month period from Sept 2012 to Aug 2017, inclusive,  qualifying events occured in only 12 months (0.2 of the total.)  So 20% seems a reasonable base rate.  That said, there has been a recent slight upsurge in the frequency of events (one in June, then three in July), which seems to have been related to the campaigning for parliamentary elections that were held in August.  Looking back at the period around the last elections, in 2012, there was no increase in these type of events. This was also the case around the elections prior to those, in 2008.  As such, I am only making a marginal increase to the base rate.

In Angola, oil and rebellion make for a potent mix for a potential perpetual separatist insurgency.  The Cabinda is a region known for ongoing attacks by the Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda.  Deep seated factionalism, kidnappings and terror attacks are notable part of the insurgent tactics.  Exogenous shocks such as external support from France with its enduring economic interests intensify he strategic interactions between MPLA and FLEC.  This part of strategic among the primary actors and secondary (but more powerful actors) has been present since its independence and into a raging Civil War.  The relatively recent entry of China into Angola has complicated the conflict further given its maximized interests in oil for infrastructure deals; this dynamic continues to occur in other African countries given its limited but critical domestic sources within its own sovereign boundaries.  Given the high rates of deaths among government soldiers in Cabinda, the counter-response from the MPLA is consistent with the dynamics of how war and conflict in general escalates.

If I read the data properly, there have been 6 fatalities to date that would fit the criteria: two in Feb, one in Jun and three in July. So, while I think it's possible, my quick scan of the news didn't turn up anything that makes me think it's probable.
